questions.text: Dr. Priya is conducting a talk on the screening of cervical cancer with a Pap smear. She works in a clinic in a low-resource setting, and she was planning to screen a woman in her 20s. Which of the following is true regarding cervical cancer screening guidelines in her workplace?

options.label: A
options.text: Co-testing (pap and Hr HPV) every 5 years starting at 25 years

options.label: B
options.text: Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 years

options.label: C
options.text: Hr HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 years

options.label: D
options.text: Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years

questions.correct_answer: B. Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 years
questions.explanation:
Population

Recommendation

Aged less than 21 years

No screening

Aged 21-29 years

Cytology alone every 3 years

Aged 30-65 years

Any one of the following:

  • Cytology alone every 3 years
  • FDA-approved primary hrHPV testing alone every 5 years
  • Cotesting (hrHPV testing and cytology) every 5 years

Aged greater than 65 years

No screening after adequate negative prior screening results

Hysterectomy with removal of the cervix

No screening in individuals without a history of high-grade cervical precancerous lesions or cervical cancer

Population

Strategy

Screening Test

Starting Age

Screening Interval

General population of women

Screen and Treat

or

Screen, Triage and Treat

HPV DNA as primary test

30 years

Every 5 to 10 years

Women living with HIV

Screen, Triage, and Treat only

HPV DNA as primary test

25 years

Every 3 to 5 years

questions.text: 26-year-old P1L1 presents with abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on the oral tablet Warfarin 3mg OD. On examination, 14 weeks of abdominal mass were felt. On USG, an 8 X 6 cm unilocular cyst with a reticular pattern was observed in the left ovary. What is the next line of management?

A couple presents with infertility even after 2 years of unprotected intercourse. The seminal analysis reveals a volume of 2 ml, concentration of 40 million/ml, progressive motility of 55%, and morphology of 45 %. The wife's hormone levels were normal, with bilateral spillage of dye from both fallopian tubes on HSG. What percentage of couples can be attributed to unexplained infertility?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1521693412001216#

Parameters

Normal (Normozoospermia)

(WHO 2021 Guidelines)

Volume

> 1.4 ml

pH

7.2-8.0

Concentration

At least 16 million/ ml

Total count

39 million/ejaculate

Total Motility

42% or more

Progressive motility

30% or more

Morphology (most important)

4% or more

Pus cells (WBC)

1-2 million/ml

Viability

54% or more

questions.text: A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge and a normal cervix. The whiff test is positive. What is this condition?

An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2, LH 0.3, and TSH 1.2. Prolactin 20ng/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
A 27-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth. What is the first line management?
questions.explanation:
Treatment

Mechanism

Benefits

OCPs (First-line for menstrual regulation & hirsutism) (Option C)

Estrogen increases SHBG, reducing free testosterone; Progestogen suppresses LH & androgen production

Regulates cycles, reduces acne & hirsutism

Anti-androgenic OCPs (Preferred)

Cyproterone acetate or Drospirenone

Best for hirsutism & acne

Spironolactone + OCPs

Blocks androgen receptors

Reduces hirsutism & acne

Eflornithine Cream (Topical)

Inhibits hair growth

Used for facial hirsutism

Drug

Mechanism

Benefits

Side Effects

Letrozole (Preferred Over Clomiphene Citrate)

Aromatase inhibitor

No anti-estrogenic effects on endometrium & cervix → higher pregnancy rates, monofollicular stimulation, no ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)

Drowsiness

Clomiphene Citrate (Option D)

Selective estrogen receptor modulator

Induces ovulation in 80%, conception in 40-45%

Anti-estrogenic effects on endometrium & cervix lower fertility, OHSS in <1%

Tamoxifen (Resistant Cases)

Estrogen receptor modulator

Used when Clomiphene fails (80-160 mg for 5 days)

–

Dexamethasone (Adjunct)

Lowers adrenal androgens

Improves ovulation outcomes

–

Drug

Mechanism

Benefits and side effects

Metformin (Option A)

Improves insulin sensitivity, reduces hepatic glucose production, lowers testosterone levels

Benefits: Increases ovulation (70-80%), conception (30-40%).
 

S/E: GI disturbances, lactic acidosis, avoid in liver/kidney disease

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) + Micronutrients

Lowers homocysteine, improves insulin resistance

Alternative to Metformin in some cases

Acarbose (Alternative to Metformin)

Delays glucose absorption

Used if Metformin is contraindicated

questions.text: OCPs are not protective for?
questions.explanation:
Cancer Type

Effect of COC Use

Key Findings

Endometrial Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by ≥30%, with greater protection in long-term users. The effect persists for years after discontinuation.
  • More pronounced reduction seen in smokers, obese women, and those with low physical activity.

Ovarian Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by 30–50%, with greater protection in long-term users. The effect persists for 10–15 years after stopping, even with short-term use (≥6 months).
  • Protection extends to BRCA1/BRCA2 mutation carriers.

Colorectal Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by 15–20%.

Breast Cancer

Increased Risk
  • COC use increases risk by 25%, especially in nulliparous women who start before age 24 and use it for >4 years.
  • If breast cancer develops, it is usually well-differentiated with a good prognosis.
  • The increased risk disappears after 10 years of stopping.

Cervical Cancer

Increased Risk
  • Prolonged COC use increases risk, particularly of adenocarcinoma of the cervix.
  • Women using COCs for ≥5 years have a higher risk, with risk increasing with longer duration.

questions.text: A 38 Y/o woman presents with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, and frequent urination. On physical examination, her uterus is found to be irregularly enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 25-year-old female presents with irregular menstrual cycles, acne, and excessive hair growth. An ultrasound reveals multiple ovarian cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of a yellowish-green, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She reports painful urination and pain during intercourse & no itching. On speculum examination, her vulva and vaginal walls appear inflamed. What is the causative agent?

A 35-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of her fertility status. She has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Which of the following is the single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve?
questions.explanation:
Test Name

Description

Key Points

Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)

A hormone produced by ovarian antral follicles.
  • Blood test reflecting the remaining quantity of eggs.
  • Not affected by the menstrual cycle.
  • The single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve

Antral Follicle Count (AFC)

Ultrasound count of the small follicles (antral follicles) within the ovaries.
  • Direct visual assessment.
  • Can vary with the cycle.
  • Baseline assessment and monitoring.

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)

Measures the level of FSH, which stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • Initial screening of ovarian function.

Estradiol (E2)

Measures the level of estradiol, an estrogen produced by growing follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • High levels can mask high FSH levels, so they are used in conjunction with FSH.

Inhibin B

Measures the level of inhibin B, which reflects the number of antral follicles.
  • Blood test on day 5 of the menstrual cycle.

Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test (CCCT)

Measures FSH and estradiol before and after taking clomiphene citrate.
  • Two blood tests: day 3 and day 10.
  • Higher FSH levels on day 10 indicate lower reserve.
  • Used for detailed functional assessment.

questions.text: Cervarix vaccine is effective against which of the following Human papillomavirus serotypes?
questions.explanation:
Girls aged 9–14 years:
  • Two doses (0 and 6 months).

Girls aged 15 years and older:

 
  • Three doses:
    • Cervarix: 0, 1, and 6 months.
    • Gardasil: 0, 2, and 6 months.

Immunocompromised individuals (any age):
  • Three doses:
    • Cervarix: 0, 1, and 6 months.
    • Gardasil: 0, 2, and 6 months

Girls aged 9–14 years:

One or two doses.

Girls and women aged 15–20 years:

One or two doses.

Women older than 21 years:

Two doses, 6 months apart.

Vaccine Type

Targeted HPV Types

Cervarix

Bivalent (types 16, 18)

Quadrivalent Gardasil

6, 11, 16, 18

Nonavalent Gardasil 9

Made from the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

Risk types of Human Papilloma Virus

Low Risk

6, 11, 42, 43, and 44.

High Risk

16, 18, 31, 33, 34, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 66, 68, and 70

16 and 18 are responsible for most cancers.

Endometrial Hyperplasia

Endometrial Cancer

questions.text: The investigation of choice for ovarian torsion is?
questions.explanation:
Ovarian Torsion - Clinical Overview

Definition

Twisting of ovary and fallopian tube around supportive ligaments

Incidence
  • 3% of gynecologic emergencies
  • 20-25% cases occur during pregnancy

Risk Factors
  • Ovarian masses (6-10 cm)
  • Pregnancy
  • Long utero-ovarian ligaments
  • Right side more common (due to sigmoid colon on left)
  • Pathologically enlarged ovaries

Clinical Presentation
  • Sharp lower abdominal pain (sudden onset)
  • Intermittent worsening
  • Localized to involved side
  • Radiation to flank, groin, or thigh
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Low-grade fever

Diagnostic Methods
  • USG Doppler (investigation of choice)
  • Shows swollen edematous ovary
  • Disruption in normal adnexal flow
  • Free fluid in peritoneal cavity

Management
  • Rapid surgical intervention
  • Detorsion recommended initially
  • Cystectomy if mass present
  • Oophorectomy if necrosis present
  • Consider ovarian conservation regardless of appearance

Pregnancy Considerations
  • Management similar to non-pregnant state
  • Progesterone support if corpus luteum removed
  • Wait 10 weeks before additional surgery

SIDE EFFECTS OF IUCD

IMMEDIATE

REMOTE

  • Syncopal attack

  • Partial or complete perforation
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • Spontaneous expulsion
  • Perforation of the uterus

Lippe’s Loop

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with intermenstrual spotting during the first month after IUCD insertion. She has no other complications. What is the most appropriate next step?
A 35-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne, excessive hair growth, and increased serum insulin and testosterone levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 26-year-old nulligravida presents with no cystocele and no rectocele but has a third-degree uterine prolapse. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Category of patient

Treatment of Uterine Prolapse

Nulliparous or congenital prolapse

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation

Pregnancy & postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks POG)
  • Pelvic floor exercises

<40 Years
  • Fothergill’s repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar’s procedure

>40 Years - with completed family

Vaginal hysterectomy & pelvic floor repair

>60 Years - unit for surgery
  • Le-fort’s repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn’t want to retain sexual function

First degree

The uterus descends downward, but the external os (opening of the cervix) remains inside the vagina.

Second degree

The uterine body remains inside the vagina while the external os protrudes outside the vaginal introitus.

Third degree (Procidentia)

The cervix, uterine body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus.

The complete uterus protrudes outside the vagina.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best post-coital contraceptive method?

A 45-year-old woman presents for her annual checkup with no specific complaints. As part of preventive screening, which cancer screening test should be prioritized based on the most common malignancy affecting females?

A 28-year-old G2P2 requests immediate postpartum contraception after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She expresses interest in an intrauterine device (IUD). What is the recommended timeframe for safe postplacental IUD insertion?
Until what time after delivery can an Intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) be inserted postpartum?
questions.explanation:
Timing Category

Guidelines

Ideal time
  • During menses or first 5 days of menstruation

Most preferred timing
  • Postpartum (immediate postpartum): Post-placental
  • Late postpartum: Within 48 hours of delivery up to 1 week
  • Postpartum reports more cases of spontaneous expulsion

Others
  • Post-puerperal: Within 6 weeks of delivery
  • Interval: Within 6 months
  • Post-coital: up to 3-5 days of unprotected intercourse
  • Post-abortion: After 1st trimester loss
    • Not recommended after 2nd trimester abortion

questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Bacterial vag

Acidic pH

Alkaline pH > 7

Candidiasis

Bacterial vaginosis

Trichomoniasis

  • Dimorphic Fungi

          Blastospores (Spreads)

          Mycelia (Invasion & adherence)

  • Curdy white discharge plaque on vaginal wall on removal causes Petechiae
  • Out of proportion Pruritus
  • Complicated / uncomplicated

Uncomplicated

  • Seen in normal women
  • Good prognosis
  • a/w albicans

Complicated

  • In immunocompromised (in DM, TB, pregnancy etc)
  • Recurrent, Severe
  • a/w non-albicans
  • Hemphilus vaginalis aka Gardenella vaginalis

AMSEL’S >/= 3 out of 4

  • Creamy discharge
  • Whift Test: +ve
    • Secretion + 10% KOH → amines
  • Fishy odour
  • Clue Cells: vaginal epithelium with embeded bacteria

Clue cells

  • No Pruritis
  • By Trichomonas vaginalis Flagellate protozoan

         Motile organism cause severe irritation &                                 severe pruritis

  • Colpitis Macularis (Strawberry Vagina)
  • Greenish yellow, Frothy discharge
  • Treatment
    • Azoles
    • Oral
    • Fluconazole
    • Rx both male & female
  • Treatment
    • METRONIDAZOLE
    • Rx the Women (no sexual transmission)
  • Treatment
    • METRONIDAZOLE
    • Rx both man & women

questions.text: A girl presented with irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth in the OPD. USG revealed multiple ovarian follicles. Which of the following would be increased in this patient?

questions.text: What is the wrong match? a. Uterine Prolapse 1. Hysterectomy b. Vault prolapse 2. Sacrospinous fixation c. Rectocele 3. Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy d. Cystocele 4. Colposuspension
questions.explanation:
Clinical features
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Pelvic discomfort
  • Anterior vaginal wall prolapse
  • Bulge shows transverse rugosities and impulse on coughing

Management

Surgical: (recommended for women >40 years)

  • Anterior Colporrhaphy: (most preferred)
    • weakened tissue between the bladder and vagina is repaired.
  • Mesh Repair:
    • synthetic mesh is used for additional support.
    • Risk of recurrence, mesh erosion and infection
  • Sacral Colpopexy:
    • Mesh is attached from the top of the vagina to the sacrum to lift the prolapsed organs.
    • High risk of recurrence and complications
  • Vaginal Hysterectomy:
    • Considered in cases where uterine prolapse coexists with cystocele.

Conservative:

  • Recommended in young women with prolapse following childbirth for the initial 4-6 months
  • Pelvic floor exercises
  • Lifestyle modifications: Avoid heavy lifting and constipation
  • Pessary insertion (in patients unfit for surgery)

questions.text: What is the use of the instrument given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B:

questions.text: In this case, a 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after experiencing bleeding from the vagina, which was preceded by a lack of menstrual periods for 7 weeks. The woman is in a state of hemodynamic shock and has a positive result for serum beta hCG. During the examination, a mass can be felt in the lower abdomen. What is the probable diagnosis in this situation?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D

questions.text: Which demographic is most likely to present with warty lesions on the vulva, along with multiple warty growths around the anal canal, as observed during examination?

A 60-year-old woman comes with chronic vulval itching and pain. On examination, there is a vulval lesion suspicious of vulval cancer. Which of the following lymph node/s should be considered for sentinel node biopsy to look for the metastatic spread?
questions.explanation:
Age Group

Most common in elderly women, especially in the 6th and 7th decades, (50-70 years age group)

Risk Factors

HPV infections, HSV infections, smoking, chronic immunosuppression, chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., lichen sclerosis).

Histological Type

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type.

Common Sites
  • Labia majora: Most common site (60%).
  • Clitoris: Second most common site (15%).

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) growth.
  • Ulcerative lesions.

Symptoms
  • Pruritus (most common), often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Swelling, lump, or ulcer.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain (late symptom).

Spread
  • Primarily through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Commonly involved lymph nodes: Inguinofemoral.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly impacts prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy: Preferred for lesions < 1 cm, for histological assessment of invasion depth.
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm.
  • Wedge biopsy, Keyes punch biopsy, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (to assess inguinofemoral node involvement).

Treatment
  • Vulvectomy: Partial or total, depending on disease stage.
  • Inguinal lymph node dissection: To evaluate disease spread.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (Superficial inguinal lymph nodes): Determines stage and prognosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has never given birth and is undergoing hormone replacement therapy (HRT) presents with abdominal pain. On examination, a non-painful palpable mass is detected in the right adnexa. Following further investigation, she undergoes laparotomy, and her ovaries are observed as described. What is the probable diagnosis?
What is the preferred diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula?
Which of the following is the most common organism causing pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.explanation:
PID

Definition

Definition

An infection and inflammation of the female reproductive organs

Causative Organisms

Commonly caused by sexually transmitted bacteria, including:

 
  • Chlamydia trachomatis

 
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Other bacteria may also be involved, such as:

 
  • Mycoplasma genitalium

 
  • Gardnerella vaginalis

Risk Factors
  • Multiple sexual partners

 
  • History of sexually transmitted infections

 
  • Previous episode of PID

Clinical Features
  • Lower abdominal pain and tenderness

 
  • Abnormal vaginal discharge

 
  • Pain during intercourse (dyspareunia)

 
  • Irregular menstrual bleeding or postcoital bleeding

Diagnosis
  • Clinical examination and history

 
  • Pelvic examination

 
  • Laboratory tests, including:

 
  • Urine analysis

 
  • Blood tests for inflammatory markers

 
  • Vaginal swabs for culture and sensitivity

 
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for specific organisms

 
  • Imaging studies (e.g., ultrasound, MRI) in complex cases

Complications
  • Tubo-ovarian abscess

 
  • Infertility

 
  • Chronic pelvic pain

 
  • Ectopic pregnancy

Treatment
  • Antibiotic therapy targeting the causative organisms

 
  • Treatment of sexual partners to prevent reinfection

 
  • Hospitalization may be necessary for severe cases or complications

Prevention
  • Safe sexual practices, including condom use

 
  • Regular screening for sexually transmitted infections

 
  • Prompt treatment of sexually transmitted infections

 
  • Vaccination against certain causative organisms (e.g., HPV)

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady presented with complaint of postcoital bleeding. On per speculum examination, the following is seen. It bleeds on touch. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Cervical

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B.

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A

Method

Description

Tubal ligation

In this surgical procedure, the fallopian tubes are blocked, cut, or sealed to prevent the sperm from reaching the egg.

Bilateral salpingectomy

This surgical procedure involves the removal of both fallopian tubes, which prevents the sperm and egg from meeting.

Hysterectomy

A surgical procedure to remove the uterus, which eliminates the possibility of pregnancy.

Oophorectomy

The surgical removal of one or both ovaries, which results in the loss of fertility.

Vasectomy

A surgical procedure for males in which the vas deferens, the tube that carries sperm from the testicles, is cut or blocked.

Essure

A device inserted into the fallopian tubes to cause scar tissue formation, blocking the tubes and preventing pregnancy.

Uterine artery embolization

A non-surgical procedure in which small particles are injected into the blood vessels supplying the uterus, causing blockage.

Endometrial ablation

A procedure that removes or destroys the lining of the uterus, preventing pregnancy.

Radiofrequency ablation

A minimally invasive procedure that uses heat energy to destroy the lining of the uterus.

Permanent contraceptive implant

A small rod or device inserted under the skin that releases hormones to prevent pregnancy for an extended period.

questions.text: What is the most suitable contraceptive method for a 34-year-old woman who has recently given birth and wishes to prevent pregnancy for the next three years?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ The most suitable contraceptive method for a 34-year-old woman who has recently given birth and wishes to prevent pregnancy for the next three years is: Option B. IUCD with progesterone: Intrauterine Contraceptive Devices (IUCDs) are long-acting and reversible contraceptive methods. They provide effective contraception for several years. There are different types of IUCDs, including those with added progesterone, which can provide additional benefits such as reduced menstrual bleeding and cramps. Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ The most suitable contraceptive method for a 34-year-old woman who has recently given birth and wishes to prevent pregnancy for the next three years is:
  • ↳ Option B. IUCD with progesterone: Intrauterine Contraceptive Devices (IUCDs) are long-acting and reversible contraceptive methods. They provide effective contraception for several years. There are different types of IUCDs, including those with added progesterone, which can provide additional benefits such as reduced menstrual bleeding and cramps.
  • ↳ Option B. IUCD with progesterone:
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Option A. Barrier methods , such as condoms or diaphragms, are effective but might not be the best choice for long-term contraception, especially if the woman wishes to prevent pregnancy for several years.
  • ↳ Option A. Barrier methods , such as condoms or diaphragms, are effective but might not be the best choice for long-term contraception, especially if the woman wishes to prevent pregnancy for several years.
  • ↳ Option A. Barrier methods
  • ↳ Option C. Injectable progesterone can be an effective contraceptive method, but it requires regular injections, which might not be the most convenient option for every woman. Option D. Nothing besides lactation amenorrhea: Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) is a natural form of contraception that relies on exclusive breastfeeding to prevent ovulation and thus pregnancy. However, it is most effective only in the first six months postpartum, and its effectiveness decreases as the baby starts to consume other foods and supplements in addition to breast milk. Therefore, it might not be a reliable option for three years of contraception. Considering the woman's desire for a long-term contraceptive method, Option B (IUCD with progesterone) would be a suitable choice. However, it's essential for her to consult with a healthcare provider to determine the most appropriate method based on her individual health needs and preferences.
  • ↳ Option C. Injectable progesterone can be an effective contraceptive method, but it requires regular injections, which might not be the most convenient option for every woman.
  • ↳ Option C. Injectable progesterone
  • ↳ Option D. Nothing besides lactation amenorrhea: Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) is a natural form of contraception that relies on exclusive breastfeeding to prevent ovulation and thus pregnancy. However, it is most effective only in the first six months postpartum, and its effectiveness decreases as the baby starts to consume other foods and supplements in addition to breast milk. Therefore, it might not be a reliable option for three years of contraception.
  • ↳ Option D. Nothing besides lactation amenorrhea:
  • ↳ Considering the woman's desire for a long-term contraceptive method, Option B (IUCD with progesterone) would be a suitable choice. However, it's essential for her to consult with a healthcare provider to determine the most appropriate method based on her individual health needs and preferences.
  • ↳ Option B (IUCD with progesterone)

questions.text: What is the stage classification for a case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm with lung metastasis?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Stage I

Cancer confined to the uterus

Stage II

Cancer spread outside the uterus but limited to genital structures (e.g., vagina)

Stage III

Cancer spread to the lungs

Stage IV

Cancer spread to other distant organs (e.g., liver, brain, kidneys)

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment choice for metropathia haemorrhagica?
What is the term used for egg cells that have been fertilized?
A 16-year-old girl with short height, amenorrhea with widely spaced nipple visited to the OPD. What is the karyotype of this female?
questions.explanation:
Chromosomal Abnormality

Defect

Characteristic Features

Turner Syndrome (45 XO)

Missing or incomplete X chromosome in females

Short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, primary ovarian insufficiency, cardiac and renal abnormalities

Down Syndrome (Trisomy 21)

Extra copy of chromosome 21

Intellectual disability, distinct facial features (such as slanted eyes and flat facial profile), low muscle tone, heart defects, gastrointestinal issues

Klinefelter Syndrome (47 XXY)

Extra X chromosome in males

Male hypogonadism, infertility, tall stature, reduced facial and body hair, gynecomastia (enlarged breast tissue)

Triple X Syndrome (47 XXX)

Extra X chromosome in females

Taller height, delayed motor and language development, mild intellectual disability, menstrual irregularities

Jacob's Syndrome (47 XYY)

Extra Y chromosome in males

Taller stature, delayed speech and language development, behavioral and learning difficulties, increased risk of developmental disorders

Cri du Chat Syndrome (5p-)

Deletion of a portion of chromosome 5

High-pitched cry resembling a cat, intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, delayed growth and development

Edwards Syndrome (Trisomy 18)

Extra copy of chromosome 18

Severe intellectual disability, multiple congenital abnormalities (e.g., heart defects, clenched fists, rocker-bottom feet), low birth weight

Patau Syndrome (Trisomy 13)

Extra copy of chromosome 13

Severe intellectual disability, cleft lip and palate, heart defects, polydactyly (extra fingers or toes), eye abnormalities

Fragile X Syndrome

Expansion of the CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome

Intellectual disability, behavioral problems, distinct facial features, large ears, hyperflexible joints

questions.text: Which of the following Spermicidal cream is used in contraception?
questions.explanation:
Chemical Contraceptive

How It Works

Advantages

Disadvantages

Nonoxynol-9

Disrupts sperm membranes, immobilizing or killing sperm
  • Readily available and affordable
  • May cause irritation or allergic reactions

Contraceptive Sponge

Contains spermicide that immobilizes or kills sperm
  • Convenient and non-hormonal
  • Less effective than some other contraceptive methods

Spermicidal Cream/Gel

Contains chemicals that immobilize or kill sperm
  • Non-hormonal and can be used on-demand
  • May cause irritation or allergic reactions

Vaginal Suppositories

Release spermicidal chemicals into the vagina
  • Easy to use and can be inserted discreetly
  • Requires insertion prior to intercourse

Vaginal Film

Dissolves and releases spermicidal chemicals in the vagina
  • Convenient and can be used on-demand
  • Requires insertion prior to intercourse

Vaginal Foam

Creates a foam that immobilizes or kills sperm
  • Easy to use and provides localized application
  • Requires insertion prior to intercourse
    - May cause irritation or discomfort

A 16 year old girl with acute bleeding per vaginal was presented to the clinic. What is immediate management ?
questions.explanation:
Cause

BLEEDING PV IN YOUNG FEMALES

Hormonal Imbalance

Irregular menstrual cycles, anovulation, or hormonal changes

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Hormonal disorder causing irregular periods

Uterine Fibroids

Noncancerous growths in the uterus

Endometriosis

Presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus

Adenomyosis

Endometrial tissue grows into the muscular wall of the uterus

Cervical Polyps

Benign growths on the cervix

Cervical Ectropion (Cervical Erosion)

Outer layer of the cervix becomes inflamed

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)

Infection of the female reproductive organs

Vaginal Infections

Bacterial or yeast infections affecting the vagina

Hormonal Contraceptive Use

Irregular bleeding as a side effect of contraceptive methods

Coagulation Disorders

Bleeding disorders affecting blood clotting

Pregnancy-related causes

Ectopic pregnancy, miscarriage, or molar pregnancy

Cervical or Endometrial Polyps

Abnormal growths in the cervix or uterus

Cervical or Endometrial Cancer

Malignant growths in the cervix or uterus

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in the case of a hypertensive and diabetic 67-year-old woman presenting with profuse vaginal bleeding?
A female presented to the clinic with complaints of amenorrhea and galactorrhea. What is he most likely diagnosis??
What is the commonly preferred contraceptive method?
questions.explanation:
Method of Contraception

Mechanism of Action

Examples

Advantages

Disadvantages

Barrier Methods

Prevent sperm from reaching the egg

Condoms, diaphragms, cervical caps
  • Provides some protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
  • Readily available and easily accessible
  • No hormonal side effects
  • Requires consistent and correct use
  • May interrupt spontaneity
  • Potential for allergic reactions

Hormonal Methods

Suppress ovulation and/or thicken cervical mucus

Combined oral contraceptives (COCs)

Progestin-only pills (mini-pills)

Contraceptive patch, vaginal ring
  • Highly effective when used correctly and consistently
  • Regulates menstrual cycles and reduces menstrual pain and bleeding
  • Reduced risk of ectopic pregnancy and certain types of cancer
  • Improved acne and reduction in symptoms of premenstrual syndrome (PMS)
  • Requires daily or regular use
  • Possible side effects such as nausea, breast tenderness, mood changes
  • May not be suitable for individuals with certain medical conditions or risk factors
  • Does not protect against STIs

Intrauterine Devices (IUDs)

Prevent fertilization and/or implantation

Copper IUDs (non-hormonal)

Hormonal IUDs (progestin-releasing)
  • Long-acting and reversible contraception
  • Highly effective with a low failure rate
  • Reduced risk of ectopic pregnancy
  • Provides long-term contraception, ranging from 3 to 10 years
  • Requires insertion by a healthcare professional
  • Possible side effects such as irregular bleeding and cramping
  • May not be suitable for individuals with certain medical conditions or risk factors
  • Does not protect against STIs

Sterilization

Permanent blocking of the fallopian tubes

Tubal ligation (for women)

Vasectomy (for men)
  • Provides permanent contraception
  • Does not require daily or regular use
  • Irreversible
  • Surgical procedure with associated risks and recovery time

Natural Methods

Monitoring fertility and avoiding intercourse

during fertile periods

Fertility awareness-based methods (tracking cycles)

Withdrawal (pull-out method)
  • No side effects
  • No hormonal or barrier-related side effects
  • Can be used by individuals who cannot or prefer not to use other methods of contraception
  • Requires commitment, consistency, and accurate monitoring
  • High failure rate if not used correctly or consistently
  • Does not protect against STIs

questions.explanation:
Emergency Contraceptive Method

Dose or Timing

Time Until Use

Copper Intrauterine Device (IUD)

Insertion of IUD within 5 days of unprotected intercourse

Within 5 days of unprotected intercourse

Levonorgestrel Emergency Contraceptive Pill (LNG ECP)

1.5 mg single dose or 0.75 mg in two doses, 12 hours apart

Within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected intercourse

Ulipristal Acetate Emergency Contraceptive Pill (UPA ECP)

30 mg single dose

Within 120 hours (5 days) of unprotected intercourse

Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (COCs)

Various regimens available, typically a high-dose of ethinyl estradiol and levonorgestrel or norgestrel

Within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected intercourse

Progestin-only Pills (POP)

Various regimens available, typically a high-dose of levonorgestrel or norgestrel

Within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected intercourse

Combined Hormonal Patch

Application of patch within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse

Within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected intercourse

Combined Hormonal Ring

Insertion of ring within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse

Within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected intercourse

Stage of Sexual Maturity

Uterus Size

Prepubertal

Small (less than 3 cm in length)

Puberty

Begins to enlarge, approximately 6-8 cm in length

Reproductive Age

Varies throughout the menstrual cycle:

  • Early follicular phase: 6-8 cm in length
  • Ovulation: 8-10 cm in length
  • Late luteal phase: 6-8 cm in length

Perimenopause

Starts to decrease in size

Postmenopause

Smaller and atrophic (less than 6 cm in length)

questions.text: What accurately describes the condition of a 22-year-old woman who complains of irregular menstrual cycles for a few months? Her cycles last 35-45 days, with a duration of 3-4 days and mild to moderate blood flow. There are no clots or dysmenorrhea.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Oligomenorrh

Menstrual Irregularity

Description

Amenorrhea

Absence of menstruation for three or more consecutive menstrual cycles.

Oligomenorrhea

Infrequent or irregular menstrual periods occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.

Polymenorrhea

Frequent or shortened menstrual cycles with intervals of less than 21 days.

Menorrhagia

Excessive or prolonged menstrual bleeding that lasts longer than 7 days or involves heavy flow.

Metrorrhagia

Irregular, unpredictable, and often heavy bleeding between menstrual periods.

questions.text: Which hormone acts on the endometrium after ovulation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Prog

Phase of Menstrual Cycle

Hormone Levels

Menstrual Phase(3 to 7 days)

Low levels of estrogen and progesterone

Follicular Phase(10 to 14 days)

Estrogen gradually increases
 

FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) increases
 

LH (Luteinizing Hormone) increases slightly near ovulation
 

Progesterone remains low

Ovulation (day 14 of a 28-day menstrual cycle)

LH surges, causing ovulation
 

Estrogen reaches its peak
 

FSH decreases
 

Progesterone starts to increase

Luteal Phase(lasts 12-14 days before menstruation)

Progesterone continues to increase
 

Estrogen starts to decline
 

LH decreases after ovulation
 

FSH remains low

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient visits the outpatient department (OPD) with a complaint of a mass descending through the vaginal opening. Upon examination, it is determined to be a second-degree uterovaginal prolapse. The patient does not have any chronic illnesses and does not smoke or consume alcohol. She has previously undergone two vaginal deliveries, one 8 years ago and the other 10 years ago with Episiotomy. The doctor proceeds to gather a detailed obstetric history pertaining to these two deliveries. Which of the following factors in the patient's history is unlikely to have contributed to her current condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D: E

questions.text: What is the conservative approach used to treat pelvic organ prolapse?
questions.explanation: Correct option C-What is the conservative approach used to treat pelvic organ prolapse?

questions.text: 28 year old lady (G2 P1) who does not want to conceive after abortion, which is the preferred mode of contraception?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B-IUD

questions.text: A 43-year-old female patient visits the doctor with concerns about her irregular menstrual periods and experiencing bleeding after sexual intercourse for the past 2 months. The patient comes from a low socio-economic background and has 4 children. She uses an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) for birth control. Additionally, the patient has a long history of smoking and has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 5 years. The patient's vital signs are stable, and the physical examination does not reveal any significant findings. Further investigations indicate a positive test for type 16 human papillomavirus (HPV) and a biopsy confirms the presence of cervical cancer in its early stage. Which of the following factors from her medical history does not contribute to her current condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B-Hypertension and IUCD u

questions.text: What is the chromosomal pattern in complete mole?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C-46 XX both paternal orig

Characteristic

Complete Mole

Incomplete Mole

Chromosomal Makeup

Completely paternal chromosomes (46, XX or 46, XY).

Abnormal chromosomal makeup, often triploid (69, XXX, 69, XXY, etc.).

questions.text: In a patient who is a 32-year-old female, experiencing her first pregnancy at full term, and has a previously diagnosed fibroid uterus, an elective cesarean section is being planned due to the baby being in a breech presentation. The patient expresses her desire to have the fibroid removed during the surgery. However, she has been informed about the potential drawbacks of undergoing myomectomy. Which of the following conditions is a reason to consider removing the fibroid in this patient?
Which of the subsequent infections is frequently associated with infertility?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A-Ch

questions.text: What initial tests should be recommended to this couple, a 29-year-old woman who has been unable to conceive for 3 years, and her husband, who have been married for 4 years, live together, and are sexually active without using contraception? The woman's menstrual cycle occurs at regular 28-day intervals, and her husband is a professional cyclist.

options.label: B
options.text: Semen analysis, Tubal patency test, Ovulation test

options.label: D
options.text: Testicular biopsy, USG, Sperm penetration test

questions.correct_answer: B. Semen analysis, Tubal patency test, Ovulation test

questions.text: Which of the following is true about endometriosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of endometrial gland in deep myometrium

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of endometrium at ectopic locations

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of endometrium at ectopic locations

Common sites

Rare sites
  • Ovaries

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of infertility in a 29-year-old female who has a history of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia?
What is the most probable reason for a 30-year-old woman visiting a clinician due to abundant facial hair and hair growth on her upper back, arms, and thighs?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B-PCOS

questions.text: What is the correct statement about the condition of a 52-year-old woman who visits a physician complaining of experiencing warm spells followed by excessive sweating, and has not had menstrual periods for the past 3 years?
A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done:
Which of the following is Hormone replacement therapy not used for?
A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?

options.label: A
options.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.correct_answer: A. Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.text: Which cervical cancer vaccination is preferred for a 16-year-old unmarried female visiting the gynecology OPD?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A: G

questions.text: Non – pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in all of the following conditions except:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B-M

Condition

Use of GnRH agonist

Endometriosis

Used to suppress estrogen production and alleviate symptoms associated with endometriosis.

Precocious puberty

Used to delay the onset of puberty and slow down the progression of sexual maturation.

Carcinoma prostate

Used in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer to suppress the production of testosterone.

questions.text: Assertion: Hot flushes are common after menopause Reason: Hot flushes are because of low estrogen or its fluctuatio

options.label: A
options.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is true, but the reason is false

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is false, but the reason is true

options.label: E
options.text: Both assertion and reason are false

questions.correct_answer: A. Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided in a 23 years old second gravida with DVT who is already on warfarin ?

questions.text: What is the appropriate approach to managing a 76-year-old woman who has a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora measuring 2 cm x 3 cm for the past 6 months, with no palpable lymph nodes, and biopsy indicating squamous cell carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Total vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: B. Radical local excision with U/L LAD

questions.text: What is the crucial indicator of male fertility in a semen analysis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A-Morpholog

questions.text: Based on the provided semen analysis results, what would be the diagnosis for a young male? The concentration is 5 million per milliliter, motility is 50%, and normal morphology is 4%.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A-Olig

Classification

Sperm Concentration per milliliter (mL)

Severe Oligospermia

Less than 5 million sperm

Moderate Oligospermia

5 million to less than 15 million sperm

Mild Oligospermia

15 million to less than 39 million sperm

Borderline Normal/Reduced

39 million to less than 55 million sperm

Normal

55 million or more sperm

questions.text: What should be the subsequent action when a patient, who has been taking MALA-N for the past 6 months and has been adhering to the medication, reports having missed periods?

options.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period

Dose

Timeframe

Levonorgestrel

1.5 mg

Within 72 hours (3 days)

30 mg

Within 120 hours (5 days)

2 pills taken in the morning and 2 pills after 12 hours

10-50 mg

options.label: B

options.label: C
